supportDesc.condition: A large irregularly shaped cave divided into two aisles by a rock buttress. The walls of the cave are full of natural fissures but also exhibit copious graffiti and carvings, including two ogham inscriptions. Some natural fissures and a rough patch at the bottom potentially obscure the beginning of the second inscription, no traces of any letters survive, and a protrubance at the top on the rock face may have served as a natural endpoint for the inscription (Forsyth 1996, 97-100). In and around the stem is a general hollowness which could be the result of water wear or chipping.

layoutDesc.layout: The inscriptions are carved on the left-hand wall of the cave, about 2m above the present floor. The area is also decorated with a panel of snake-like, loose spiral interlace graffiti (Forsyth 1996, 94-5). At a similar height to the first inscription (S-BUT-001) is the second inscription which is about 11 m from the entrance of the cave. It is possible that the inscription might have commenced lower down, in the rough patch immediately before the start of the extant portion of the text. The inscription is unlikely to have extended higher because of a protrubance on the rock face (ibid. 97). The stem leans slightly to the right as if the upper part was getting beyond the reach of the carver, suggesting that the inscription was intended to be read from the bottom upwards (ibid. 98).

handDesc.handNote: The second inscription has a near vertical stem-line but is carved in a different 'hand' from the first inscription. The strokes and letters are more widely spaced, less carefully parallel and of a more varied length than the first inscription. The strokes appear V-shaped in section and are slashed across the surface of the rock. Some strokes, especially to the right of the stem, seem exceptionally long, appearing to extend into the natural fissures (Forsyth 1996, 97).

history.provenance: Located in a sandstone cliff about 3km north of Blackwaterfoot are a series of caves of which the King's Cave at Drumadoon (Druim an DÃºin 'ridge of the fort') is the largest. The walls of the cave exhibit carvings which span from perhaps the Bronze Age to the present day. The animal and geometric carvings have been known since at least the end of the seventeenth century, but the first ogham inscription, Blackwaterfoot 1 (S-BUT-001), was not noticed until about 1968 (Forsyth 1996, 94). Though only a short distance away, this inscription, the second of the two ogham inscriptions Blackwaterfoot 2, was not discovered until 1992 by Ian Fisher of the RCAHMS while conducting further survey work on the cave (Forsyth 1996, 94).

div.p: The name Vuedla calls to mind the uidlua, 'wise woman, witch' from *wid which means 'to see, to know', of the famous Gualish inscription from Larzac (Forsyth 1996, 99).
The Irish reflex (*widlma) appears as the name of the seeress Fedelm, in TÃ¡in BÃ³ Cuailgne, and of a number of famous early Irish women, legendary and historical (Forsyth 1996, 99).

The inscription is an example of simple Type II inscriptions lacking the late features so they should be placed near the beginning of the Type II series. According to Forsyth, At best this would offer a relative date, but since simple Type II ogham continued in use alongside more ambitious, formal varieties of the script, inscriptions using this form cannot be closely dated. They could be as early as the Pool ogham (sixth century) or later than Dunadd (late eighth century?) (ibid. 99).

That the two ogham inscriptions, Blackwaterfoot 1 (S-BUT-001) and Blackwaterfoot 2, are contemporary with one another or with any other of the carvings in the cave cannot be proved (ibid. 95). However, it is clear that both are examples of casual graffiti.
